factoid: The band struck up the newly introduced mazurka.

Nicholas asked Sónya to dance.
Denísov sat down by the old ladies.
Denísov leaned on his saber.
Denísov beat time with his foot.
Denísov told the old ladies something funny.
Denísov kept the old ladies amused.
Denísov watched the young people dancing.
Iogel danced with Natásha.
Iogel is Denísov's pride.
Iogel is Denísov's best pupil.
Iogel and Natásha were the first couple.
Iogel stepped skillfully with his little feet in low shoes.
Iogel stepped noiselessly.
Natásha was shy.
Natásha carefully executed her steps.
Denísov did not take his eyes off Natásha.
Denísov beat time with his saber.
Denísov's beating time indicated that if he was not dancing it was because he would not and not because he could not.
Denísov beckoned to Rostóv.
Rostóv was passing.
Denísov said, "This is not at all the thing."
Denísov said, "What sort of Polish mazuwka is this?"
Denísov said, "But she does dance splendidly."
Denísov had a reputation even in Poland for the masterly way in which he danced the mazurka.
Nicholas ran up to Natásha.
Nicholas told Natásha, "Go and choose Denísov."
Nicholas told Natásha, "Denísov is a real dancer."
Nicholas told Natásha, "Denísov is a wonder."
Natásha had a turn to choose a partner.
Natásha rose.
Natásha tripped rapidly across in her little shoes trimmed with bows.
Natásha ran timidly to the corner where Denísov sat.
Natásha saw that everybody was looking at her.
Natásha saw that everybody was waiting.
Nicholas saw that Denísov was refusing.
Denísov was refusing.
Denísov smiled delightedly.
Nicholas ran up to them.
Natásha said, "Please, Vasíli Dmítrich, do come!"
Denísov replied, "Oh no, let me off, Countess."
Nicholas said, "Now then, Váska."
Denísov said jokingly, "They coax me as if I were Váska the cat!"
Natásha said, "I'll sing for you a whole evening."
Denísov said, "Oh, the faiwy! She can do anything with me!"
Denísov unhooked his saber.
Denísov came out from behind the chairs.
Denísov clasped his partner's hand firmly.
Denísov threw back his head.
Denísov advanced his foot.
Denísov waited for the beat.
Denísov's short stature was not noticeable only on horseback and in the mazurka.
Denísov looked like a fine fellow he felt himself to be.
Denísov looked sideways at his partner with a merry and triumphant air.
Denísov stamped with one foot.
Denísov bounded from the floor like a ball.
Denísov flew round the room taking his partner with him.
Denísov glided silently on one foot half across the room.
Denísov seemed not to notice the chairs.
Denísov was dashing straight at them.
Denísov clinked his spurs.
Denísov spread out his legs.
Denísov stopped short on his heels.
Denísov stood for a second.
Denísov stamped on the spot clanking his spurs.
Denísov whirled rapidly round.
Denísov struck his left heel against his right.
Denísov flew round again in a circle.
Natásha guessed what Denísov meant to do.
Natásha abandoned herself to Denísov.
Natásha followed Denísov's lead hardly knowing how.
Denísov spun Natásha round.
Denísov held Natásha with his left hand.
Denísov held Natásha with his right hand.
Denísov fell on one knee.
Denísov twirled Natásha round him.
Denísov jumped up.
Denísov dashed so impetuously forward that it seemed as if he would rush through the whole suite of rooms without drawing breath.
Denísov suddenly stopped.
Denísov performed some new and unexpected steps.
Denísov smartly whirled his partner round in front of her chair.
Denísov drew up with a click of his spurs.
Denísov bowed to Natásha.
Natásha did not even make Denísov a curtsy.
Natásha fixed her eyes on Denísov in amazement.
Natásha smiled as if she did not recognize Denísov.
Natásha asked, "What does this mean?"

Everyone was delighted with Denísov’s skill.
Denísov was asked again and again as a partner.
The old men began smilingly to talk about Poland and the good old days.
Denísov was flushed after the mazurka.
Denísov mopped himself with his handkerchief.
Denísov sat down by Natásha.
Denísov did not leave Natásha for the rest of the evening.
For two days after that, Rostóv did not see Dólokhov at Rostóv's home.
For two days after that, Rostóv did not see Dólokhov at Dólokhov's home.
On the third day, Rostóv received a note from Dólokhov.
Dólokhov said, "I do not intend to be at your house again for reasons you know of."
Dólokhov said, "I am going to rejoin my regiment."
Dólokhov said, "I am giving a farewell supper tonight to my friends."
Dólokhov said, "Come to the English Hotel."
